title: Are we born with free will or at some point in our lives we are given free will? - Quora

response.answer_text: We are born with free will, but it is not infinite. Our will is limited by physics, our environment, our abilities, etc. I may have the will to defy gravity, but gravity will always win. I may have the will to be an opera star, but if I am tone deaf, I’ll starve. Free will just means we are able to make choices within certain boundaries. Even when we can exercise our free will, we cannot always control the consequences—good or bad—of our choices. I disagree that the existence of an omniscient God negates our free will. It is not true that “where there is foreknowledge, there can be no free will.” It could just as easily be argued that “if there are no ‘do-overs’, there is no free will.” If we are “stuck” with our choices, the future simply becomes the past that hasn’t happened yet! It also doesn’t matter what you “believe”. I submit that if free will exists, it exists whether you believe it does or not; conversely, if it doesn’t exist, it doesn’t matter if you believe it does. Regardless, everyone lives as though it does exist! I had an atheist/Objectivist friend once and we were discussing free will. I asked him if the mind was the same as the brain or were they separate. He was adamant that they were the same; to accept a mind apart from a physical brain would be tantamount to admitting that “something” existed outside the physical realm. Heresy! Ayn Rand would roll over in her grave! So I asked him about our actions, our choices. He said that “every action is preceded by a thought (except for the autonomous nervous system, of course). If I move my hand, it is because my mind is telling it to move. Signals are being sent from my brain through my nerves down my arm to my hand and it moves.” “Awesome! So what causes the thought?” “A series of neurochemical reactions in the brain; like a chain reaction.”* “So, it’s like dominoes.” “Exactly.” “So, your ‘will’ pushes the ‘first’ domino?” “Uhh…yes…” “Then your ‘will’ is just another domino. If it’s all a purely physical construct, there are simply an infinite number of dominoes, but your SELF, your WILL doesn’t exist in infinity. Your will must exist outside the physical or it’s just another stage in the neurochemical reaction that ‘causes’ your choices, which are not really choices because you can’t be causing them. Your like a machine, a computer.” “Well, I guess so…” “Then there is no free will.” The next day, I saw him. He said that he had to change his mind, that he was not just a machine or a computer, but…he would have to think about it before he could come up with a better solution. (“Every thought you have causes neurochemical changes…” How Your Thoughts Change Your Brain, Cells, And Genes - The Best Brain Possible, my reference, not his. If it is a thought that causes the neurochemical change, then the thought must occur outside that physical process! As to the question, What comes first, the neurochemical event or the thought, the theories are all over the map!)

There are reasonable arguments to be made that there is no free will at all, so the concept of when we get it seems secondary. I’ve given this much thought, and although I can find no evidence to refute determinism (the idea of no free will), I still believe we have it (just because I can't prove it doesn't mean it’s not true). If we accept that adult humans have free will, at what point do we accept it in other living beings? Do dogs have free will, do ants, do amoebas, do plants? Is an autonomous response free will (I’d say no), but there’s a wide range of varying degrees between a single cell and an adult human. We might try to tie free will to self awareness; I think one could make a reasonable argument for that, but we still end-up on the same slippery slope. Getting back to the question of whether we (humans) are born with free will, my guess would be—yes, we do have free will (of sorts) at birth, but where along the path from conception to birth it is obtained is a much more-difficult question.

“Free will” is a narrative, a conceptualisation of a perceived experience that doesn’t really match the phenomena it describes, as it relies on the assumption that our “self” is somehow separate from our physical bodies. As perceived realities go, it’s not a bad analogy, but analogies are only good for basic description and not for argument or seeking deeper truths. A better word to use is “agency”, and yes, we are born with it. When a baby is hungry and cries out for attention, that is an act of agency, even if the baby isn’t fully aware of what it’s doing or what it hopes to achieve in doing so. As the brain develops, a child will naturally become more aware of what actions have what effects, and can therefore experience the sensation of “choosing” an action to attain a desired result, but at a biological level this is merely a more sophisticated version of the agency already exercised from day one.

New born babies are 100% feeling creatures who respond to need, and by and large, mothers are keen to satisfy those needs. But then the baby gets a bit older and eventually learns to crawl, and the first thing it does is to make its way to the wall and rip out the speaker wires that you have so painstakingly nailed to the skirting board. The child then makes it way into your library and proceeds to pull out all of the books from their shelves. Next, it will open the drawers of your desk and remove all the items. If you try to outwit it by securing restraints, the child will do its upmost to circumvent this by pulling on the drawers even harder. Now, some parents are overjoyed with all of this and say things like: ‘oooh look, our little Johnny’s such a naughty boy,’ and basically let the kid destroy everything in the house. This child undoubtedly has free will. However, other parents are not so forgiving, and they will find ways to curb Junior’s enthusiasm that restricts its movement and freedom of expression, and with it a loss of free will because the child soon learns there are things he mustn’t do. Thus, the process of growing up is the extent to which freedom of expression is inhibited or curtailed – which I think is a better term than free will, and this applies equally to the things we think as well as what we are permitted to do.

“Free will” is an interesting idea, and it depends on what you believe. If you believe in God (the monotheistic kind), there is no free will. The all-powerful being knew everything you would do before it created you. If you believe in a deterministic universe, there is no free will. Everything happens due to processes that occurred before that action was taken. It does have the semblance of free will, such that unless you know the exact state of every particle in the universe exactly as it burst into existence, you can’t know the future 100% (but it is technically possible). If you don’t believe in a deterministic universe, and also don’t believe in an omnipotent god, then you have free will. Things that happened in the past don’t 100% determine the future, so you’re good to go. Hope this helped :) Oh, almost forgot—regardless of your belief, whether or not you have free will does not depend on any action you take, so the answer to your question would be “born with it”.

‘Man is born free, but everywhere he is in chains’ - Rousseau. Rousseau - an individualist like most everybody on this earth - could not suspect what a great truth he was enunciating. The point is that existence and any will attached to it is not ‘ours’, but comes from ‘above’. By ‘above’ I mean pure consciousness rather than a god. Being, consciousness, and love are life ingredients, which, all together, make up our constitution or essence. Life is innocent and free, but ‘the gods’ instilled a seed of egoity in us so that there could be a performance, a play. Only when a rare one realizes that he is neither an actor nor the author of the play, that it was all for diversion or entertainment, does s/he gain back his real nature, which is free, unbound consciousness.

Yes, you have free will. You are born with it. You are able to exercise it at a very early age; when you become aware of your environment and how it responds to your actions. You learn from the moment you are born how to exercise it in this reality. Philosophically speaking, the concept of free will is a long discussed topic dating back to the ancient Greeks. With respect to the Judaeo-Christian God, what does free will mean? It means simply this: do you align your will with God’s or not? What does it mean to align one’s will to God’s? It means to act in a loving way to others; putting other’s needs before your own. That’s all. You’re free to disagree.

We are born with it and only realize it later in our lives through our learnings and experiences. Free will is the individual’s will to accept or reject a circumstance, a person or an object based on their understanding, experiences and beliefs. So, one needs to have maturity and knowledge to understand the gravitas of the situation before exercising one’s will. No one, including the creator can go against free will. One should also have the maturity and strength to face the consequences created by choosing the free will.

“Are we born with free will or at some point in our lives we are given free will?” We are born with Free Will. We began to lose it immediately. For instance: We are rapidly relieved of the options on crying to get nourishment, crapping in our britches and having it cleaned up for us, throwing fits as a negotiating tactic, etc.

God has a plan for each one of us humans but majority chose to do what we want to do rather than the God instructs us to do.  God tells and warns us about our wrong thinking and the acts but we often ignore and do it anyway.  God also knows it and he tells us that you have a choice but my way is the best for you.  It seems negative for you at the beginning or you do not desire to do what I tell you; thus you have to face the consequences of your own acts.
Neither. The simple truth is, at some point in our lives, we develope the illusion that we have free will. I'm not sure why or how this desire to be in control arises.

We have free will. It is fact. Of course, in some unforeseen reality, it could be that we don’t, but this is as rare as murder being God’s intentions for our existence or some other crazy shit like that. We have free will, and that is why evil exists, however, if we had no free will, life would be meaningless, boring, and unending.

I would simply ask - could we have acted differently in past, everything else remaining the same? While we weigh options, we try to weigh pros and cons, but ultimately take one decision. How did we arrive at that and is it possible that we could have acted differently at that moment? Do we act or all our actions are output of a very complex algorithm ? Everything that is made of matter, will follow laws of nature. What part of ours is made of matter and what isn't?
When, being the smallest child that you can remember, did you not want what you wanted? All living things have free will. It is a fact of life. How is this a question at all?
Free will is bestowed upon you the moment you can choose the next thought that enters your head. Good luck with that.
